title: Will any NATO member invoke Article 4 or Article 5 before 1 January 2018?
preds: I doubt that anything will happen in the next week.

Takes time to invoke those articles, and not enough time left in year. Precedence of number of times the articles have been invoked does not lead us to believe something sufficiently significant will occur. No pressing threat (but always a possibility). It's Christmas (out of office)
It is extremely unlikely given the political firestorm it would cause within NATO, but not entirely impossible.

Nobody is going to call an Article 5 unless M. Petits-Doigts makes it very clear what he thinks about all this, using "thinks" in its loosest possible meaning.   Not much chance of that. If I were a member state tempted to ask for an Article 4 schmoozefest, I'd call up the US and get some sort of okey-dokey first.  Not clear who could usefully take the call, though--Tillerson has no apparent influence and President Littlefingers is a rebel without a clue.  Maybe the daughter or the deeply magnificent son-in-law could approve the request, which would paint Daddy into a corner--he'll weasel out of his own obligations with breathtaking alacrity, but wouldn't do anything to embarrass the Golden Children.  Strange days, in case I have forgotten to mention that lately.
Up 3% on DPRK missile test and the upcoming European meetings. Never hurts to wag the dog.
Down 3% since the consensus has dropped.
Up 5% on both Syria and DPRK worries. (Yes, both are out of area.)
only a hunch. My feeling is NATO members are going to be wary about using this route to solve problems.

Article 4 and Article 5 are very different parts of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.  Article 4 essentially states any member country can bring any issue to the table and all NATO members must listen.  Turkey has similar issues as the ones that caused the invocation of Article 4 in 2015.  The differences between Article 5 and Article 4 are extreme.  Article 5 could be called a declaration of world war.  The only time in NATO history Article 5 was invoked was 9/11.  I believe no NATO country will invoke Article 4 or Article 5 before the end of this year.    http://www.nato.int/cps/ro/natohq/topics_49187.htm  Article 4
 http://www.nato.int/cps/cn/natohq/topics_110496.htm Article 5
M. Petits-Doigts has said he now believes in the principles underlying Article 5.  Nobody thinks he understands what this means in practice, so nobody will invoke this while he is in the Whine House

Given the issues around the globe of late, this seems more possible than normal. But the likelihood is still low especially with potentially increased provocations from Russia and the U.S
Russia calming down, so much less likely now then some months ago

Been involved 6 times in last 20 years and we're 1/3 of the way done with this year. However turkey would be most likely but they're fighting forces bolstered by the US. Invoking article 4 doesn't appear to be something you'd do when in disagreement with a fellow NATO member.
Up 5% on reports of the US planning to arm the "bad Kurds."
Down 10% to be below the consensus. Now that NATO is great and relevant again, why the need? (But adjusting mostly because things in Syria haven't gotten even more out of hand.)
No Nato force other than Turkey is in the direct line of fire of any of the large scale hot conflicts.
Regression to the mean says probability should be lower than last few years of unusually high activity. I started on 50%.

Since 2000 they have been used on five occasions. (Thrice by Turkey) (In 2014 all the Baltics used it the same time responding to Crimea, counts as one event) (After 9-11 USA used it) Base rate of 5/17 = 30%. We adjust downards by 66% (how much of the year we have left, and arrive at 20%. Should we adjust upwards or downwards? Feels like we have more to fear now than 9-10 in US or 2013 in Crimea. But I want data. I guess what might trigger articles will have to do with US-wars and volatility around Europe. Russian aggression has escalated. No new Russian wars btw 2000 and 2007. Since 2008 we have 3 of them. Let's say Russia can be expected to cause 20% of Article triggers and Russia-threat is 50% higher than in our sample. 20% are caused by black swans (9/11) and remain unchanged. 60% are caused by mid-east/arab-world. Risk factor from Arab world we can adjust upwards by 100% Time for maths. Base rate = 30%
Our estimate this far = 30% * 0.2 + 30% * 0.2 * 1.5 + 30% * 0.6 * 2 = 50% ! Is this feasible? A higher than 50% likelihood per year (mind that the 50% is for the remainder of 2017). Just sounds silly. But I do not think the numbers are wrong. We have seen something similar to this in recent years. Turkey used it twice in 2012, once in 2014, and that is also when the Balts used it. Turkey considered using it in 2015.  One could try analyzing Erdogan, Putin and Trump for their influence on this. Seems to murky for me.
Up 15% since northern Syria is getting even more complicated.
Down 5% for passage of time and no immediate US-DPRK crisis.
Back up 5% on news that the US White House will brief all Senators Wednesday. Could be just brinksmanship, but the UNSC meeting might be instructive.

Putin Has Eastern Europe Hearing Trump's Call to Arms Eglitis (2017) April 10, states that: Proximity to Russia is bolstering defense expenditure across eastern Europe, right at a time when Donald Trump is signaling U.S. military backing could depend on those nations paying their way inside NATO. Romania, Lithuania and Latvia – mindful of shared land and maritime borders with their former Soviet master – are behind this year’s biggest advances. Other front-line countries such as Estonia and Poland also spend more proportionally than western members, meeting or surpassing the 28-nation alliance’s guideline of allocating 2 percent of economic output. Those that feel “most exposed” to the threat from Russia “are generally readier to boost their defense budgets,” Tony Lawrence, a research fellow at the International Centre for Defense and Security, said by email. “The Trump administration is merely following – albeit more aggressively – a long-standing and not entirely unfair American complaint that European allies aren’t pulling their weight.” Eastern Europe was jolted when President Vladimir Putin annexed Crimea from Ukraine in 2014, and Trump’s remarks haven’t been forgotten despite assurances of continued U.S. support from elsewhere in his administration. While Russia often denies it has designs on places such as the Baltics, ties with those countries remain frosty. Elsewhere, in Hungary for example, relations with Putin have improved and defense expenditure has grown by less (para. 1-4). Eglitis, A. (2017). Putin Has Eastern Europe Hearing Trump's Call to Arms. Bloomberg. Market Watch. Retrieved from
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-10/putin-has-eastern-europe-hearing-trump-s-call-to-arms

The only small scenario I can imagine for invoking article 5 would be a large-scale IS attack in Turkey, and I don't believe the organization currently has the capacity for that. So, 1% for that. 
Article 4 is a little more complex, it's only been invoked five times in NATO's history but all five have been since 2003 so it's clearly getting more frequent. Unless a new actor emerges in Syria (always a possibility) I don't think Turkey will invoke article 4, nor do I think Poland will about Ukraine unless the situation becomes notably worse. The only possibility that I think would result in an article 4 invocation would be Russian military or asymmetric provocations in the Baltic countries. So, 3% for each country.

China, Russia block U.N. council concern about Myanmar violence Nichols (2017) Fri Mar 17, states that: China, backed by Russia, blocked a short U.N. Security Council statement on Myanmar on Friday, diplomats said, after the 15-member body met to discuss the situation in Rakhine state, where the country's military is conducting a security operation.
The U.N. human rights office last month accused the military of mass killings and rapes of Rohingya Muslims and burning their villages since October in a campaign that "very likely" amounts to crimes against humanity and possibly ethnic cleansing.
U.N. political affairs chief Jeffrey Feltman briefed the council behind closed doors. Britain requested the meeting.
"We did put forward ... some proposed press elements but there was not consensus in the room," British U.N. Ambassador Matthew Rycroft, president of the council for March, told reporters after the briefing.
Such statements have to be agreed by consensus. Diplomats said Myanmar neighbor China, backed by Russia, blocked the statement (para. 1-5). Nichols, M. (2017). China, Russia block U.N. council concern about Myanmar violence. . Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-un-idUSKBN16O2J6

NATO has more members and possibly more nervous members as a group than in the pre 2003 past and it could suit a number of members political objectives to draw attention to their part in the alliance.  Think very low chance of an Art 5, but think the question relies on Art 4 (the constraint isn't Art 5 since it is an 'or' question).

Article 4
The Parties will consult together whenever, in the opinion of any of them, the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened.
Article 5
The Parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all and consequently they agree that, if such an armed attack occurs, each of them, in exercise of the right of individual or collective self-defence recognised by Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, will assist the Party or Parties so attacked by taking forthwith, individually and in concert with the other Parties, such action as it deems necessary, including the use of armed force, to restore and maintain the security of the North Atlantic area.
Any such armed attack and all measures taken as a result thereof shall immediately be reported to the Security Council. Such measures shall be terminated when the Security Council has taken the measures necessary to restore and maintain international peace and security . In theory, Articles 4 and 5 can only be invoked at the request of a NATO member. However, Article 5 has only been invoked once -- immediately following the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks against the United States.
Article 5 was not invoked in other cases when it theoretically might have -- such as the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin incident, the 1968 Pueblo incident, or the 1982 Falklands War -- because it was not requested.
All major NATO decisions are made by consensus, so any invocation of Article 5 would require the consent of all 28 members. Article Four went neglected throughout the cold war, the most dangerous period of NATO's history. The first time it was called upon was in 2003, when Turkey invoked it to ask the allies for protection from Saddam Hussein during the American invasion of Iraq. Apart from last year, when Poland and Lithuania jointly requested an Article Four consultation after Russia's annexation of Crimea, Turkey seems to be the only country that has ever used it, and may be developing a bit of a habit. Turkey wants NATO to express support for its efforts to combat both IS and the PKK. But while NATO is pleased with Turkey's newfound eagerness to fight IS, it is hesitant about Turkey's aims towards the Kurds.  The Kaliningrad question:
After eastern Ukraine, the next most likely targets for an attempted Russian coercion are in the Baltic Republics of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania.  Putin is motivated by several objectives:
• To subject the Baltic democracies to various forms of hybrid warfare and to compel them, like Finland during the Cold War, to surrender their foreign relations to Moscow. 
• To virtually destroy the EU and NATO. Until recently, this claim would be deemed delusional, but today it is plausible as a consequence of Brussels’s mounting difficulties—the euro crisis, Brexit, the unprecedented rush of migrants from the Middle East and Africa to its shores, and the surging power of EU rejectionists. In addition, most NATO members have not met the requirements of the Rome Treaty to spend 2 percent of their GNP on defense. 
Furthermore, President Trump may shower America’s allies with rhetorical support, but Putin believes he will not do anything of substance to sustain the Euro-Atlantic security system. On February 10, Vladimir Putin decreed the maximum state of alert of the Russian air force by ordering his generals to stand on foot of war. Could the master of the Kremlin venture to test Donald Trump by attacking the Baltic countries? "
The View from Poland, the Russian threat is very serious. Foreign Minister Witold Waszczykowski does not mince words.
https://www.rts.ch/info/monde/8405161-kaliningrad-pourrait-etre-le-detonateur-d-un-prochain-conflit-mondial.html
_______________________________
COMMENTS:  Because of the Kaliningrad situation I would give some chances of invoking Art. 4 (not by Turkey this time), but perhaps the Baltics. Trump presidency doesn't help much, and Putin may consider the present situation the chance of a lifetime.

Wary of divided loyalties, a Baltic state reaches out to its Russians Scrutton and Mardiste (2017) Fri Feb 24, states that: It is a sign of the times in Estonia, a Baltic state always suspicious of the Kremlin's ambitions in the region, that Prime Minister Juri Ratas is learning Russian. Worried that divided loyalties in its largely Russian-speaking border areas could lay Estonia open to conflicts like those in eastern Ukraine and Crimea, Estonia wants to better integrate its Russian speaking minority. Estonia and the other Baltic nations look at Russia's actions in Ukraine and fear they could easily be overrun by their huge neighbor. By reaching out to his country's Russian-speakers, Ratas is hoping to bolster national unity and remove a possible pretext for Russian intervention. So while Ratas is taking language lessons, his new government is trying to make it easier for Russian speakers to obtain Estonian citizenship and to improve the border region's economy, where unemployment is high. Out of a population of 1.3 million in the euro zone and NATO member, about quarter are Russian speakers. Most of those have Russian passports or do not have any citizenship.
For a graphic on Russians in Estonia, click tmsnrt.rs/2meQVUw Some security analysts say any grievance amongst Russian speakers that they feel they are "second-class citizens" could give the Kremlin a pretext to intervene. Worried since Russia's 2014 seizure of Crimea that Moscow could invade Poland or the Baltic states, NATO is bolstering its eastern flank with troops and equipment. But a perception that U.S. President Donald Trump may prove soft on the Kremlin, combined with fears about "fake news" stirring tensions as NATO troops arrive, has caused concern among the Baltic nations of Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia. Latvia and Estonia have large Russian-speaking populations, the result of migration when they were under Soviet rule. But only in Estonia has a party with a Russian-speaking electoral base come to power in a ruling coalition (para. 1-10). Scrutton, A. & Mardiste, D. (2017) Wary of divided loyalties, a Baltic state reaches out to its Russians. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-baltics-russia-idUSKBN1630W2

(no change) I've been on the wrong side of all these questions in the past. One thought experiment is to consider whether frequent uses of Article 4 might lesson its utility. (I'm not particularly saying it has been used too often, but it is in the eye of the forecaster/NATO member.)  YMMV, but I almost completely discount invoking Article 5. If something that bad were to happen, NATO Hq in Brussels might be a smoking hole before then.

If I were a sentient NATO member, aware of the announced or implied unreliability of the US commitment to NATO, I would be very reluctant to put it to the test just now even if an occasion presented itself.

It is very unlikely that an event will occur with such severity that a member of NATO would resort to invoking Article 4.   Add to this the fact that the Trump administration has shown some concern regarding Article 4 and that raises even higher the level of need an event would have to meet before a NATO member would try to invoke the Article.

The articles don't have to be invoked in response to a Russian action. They can be invoked as in 2001, when the U.S. invoked Article 5 as a result of the al-Qaeda attack of September 11. I think it's possible that either article will be invoked in response to an attack by ISIS.
I can't see Russia doing anything new in Europe. That has to be the biggest threat to Europe right now

Article 5 has only be invoked once: after 9/11. Article 4 has been invoked 5 times, 4 times by Turkey (Iraq War 2003, clashes with Syria in 2012 x 2, Islamic State in 2015) and once by Poland (Crimean annexation, 2014). Thus, I foresee 4 possibilities where either Article is invoked:
1) Another 9/11-like attack. The probability will be extremely low with improved security, screening, etc. Random attacks will still occur but likely committed by foreign individuals or legal residents, and hence, not an attack on sovereignity (<1%)
2) Direct Russian invasion of a NATO member. Again, very extremely unlikely (<1%)
3) Turkey. Unlike the recent past, its southern border is now relatively secure - Syria is weakened by its civil war and the Islamic State in Iraq has lost significant territory and is busy defending Mosul from US coalition forces. (2%)
4) Ukraine. Russian experts now believe Russia's goals are not to retain physical control of illegally seized territory but to use it as a bargaining chip to "make a deal" with the West and establish a quasi-independent pro-Russian foothold. Thus, Poland and other neighbors are unlikely to perceive a territorial threat. (2%) http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-iraq-mosul-offensive-20170218-story.html
http://stream.wsj.com/story/deadly-clashes-in-ukraine/SS-2-457850/
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/feb/14/avdiivka-frontline-ukraine-war-russia-backed-separatists

Trump complicates everything, but this actually makes it even less likely for Russia to do something. From my experience watching Ukraine, Putin prefers an incredibly murky and off-balance status quo to outright confrontation. He has that with Trump. Pence went to Munich security conference and said opposite of much of what Trump has said. Furthermore, even if Putin went into Estonia for some reason, it is not clear that (1) the overwhelming evidence needed for Article 5 would be present and (2) west wouldn't find a way to weasel out of invoking it because of their own problems.
The real situation and what is really happening is going to more invoke not lees

Invoking article 4 is not a very significant event and can be called readily. The base rate of article 4, is approx 4 / 16 a year. I have adjusted slightly higher given the tension in Eastern Europe.

It looks like from 2001 to 2017 there were 6.  I may be miscounting the final Turkey Article 4 invoke, but there was at least an intention. ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty ).  The crudest possible model is 6 invocations per 16 years, or, if they were evenly distributed, ~.38/year. I'll start with 38%.  Next step would be to look at possible individual hot spots.

(no change for now) If I thought that NATO would have a significant role related to Russia and the INF Treaty I'd go higher related to an Article 4 discussion. Based on a failing memory, it seems like most INF stuff has been handled in the past by various standing committees or direct discussions between the US and USSR. I think NATO mostly provided a rubber stamp (and weighed in with the Dual Track Decision related to dealing with theater strategic missiles). Since the current US President is probably (we think) not a fan of multi-lateral negotiations or NATO, I see no reason for the US side to offer the portfolio to NATO and doubt Putin would do anything to encourage NATO involvement.

I mostly concur with @JakkeMakela comments below, however estimating the probability following from his line of thought substantially lower, at around 10%. In addition to the possible invocations points for articles 4 and 5 we had few months ago, we now face a new possibility. In order to legitimize domestic policies, certain largest NATO partner may turn their eyes towards possible enemies abroad and seek non-disputable support from their allies via art 4 or 5. As far-fetched as it might sound, I see this as biggest single threat right now.

As estimated by  @AvJo, base rate for last 5 years is 60%. I would expect the probability to be quite a bit lower, since 
a) Uncertainty about Trump regime raises bar to call on the Articles
b) Most NATO countries are now pretty resigned to terrorist attacks
c) There isn't much Russia can do without launching WW III, which I don't expect them to want to do. Pressure on the Baltic states could trigger the Articles, but also huge risks. I find it extremely unlikely.

lack of response to many long-standing conflicts that continue to this day

Historically the probability is 6 invocations in 5 years over 68 years, i.e. 7.4%, and article 4 (consultation) represents 5/6 invocations. Looking at the last five years, the probability is 4 invocations in 3 years over 5 years, i.e. 60%. 
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO Is the current political landscape more or less probable than the last five years to cause Nato members to consult / call to aid the member states?
Lower probability:
- Syria
- Terrorist attacks (Nato members should have gotten used to them)
- Crimea
- 1.5 months of 2017 gone by without incident
Pot. higher probability:
- New Russian incursions into Eastern Europe
- Testing Trump -> What do you think?

Article4 and Article 5 of NATO's treaty among various states elaborate on the consultation and Collective Defense policies.  While the risks for conflict (2017) appears > or = 2016, it seems unlikely that the magnitude of the crises would warrant use of these two articles.   NATO has on only one occasion in its history implemented these policies (ie., 9/11).   It is unlikely to do so unless the magnitude of an explosive crises emerges.  Candidates for such conflict interactions are the US vs. Russia or US vs. China
